summary: The case of Ellis Tamakloe v. The Republic was heard by the Supreme Court of Ghana, involving an appeal against a conviction and sentence. The court considered issues relating to criminal procedure, fairness of trial, and application of evidence. The appellant challenged the lower court's interpretation of facts and procedural conduct during trial. The Supreme Court evaluated whether there were breaches of natural justice and due process, particularly focusing on the right to a fair hearing and proper judicial conduct. After review, the court dismissed the appeal, affirming the decision of the lower court.
rationaleHighlights: No breach of natural justice found
Appellant had fair opportunity to present defense
Procedural objections raised were deemed without merit
